case_name: Municipal Committee of Amravati v. Respondent No. 1

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 598 of 1962 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1961 of the Maharashtra High Court Nagpur Bench at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 30 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 18, 1961 of the Maharashtra High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 30 of 1960.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 695 and 700 of 1962 are appeals from judgments dated October 12, 1961 and March 18, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 122 of 1961 and 319 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: WITH Civil Appeals Nos. 695 and 700 of 1962. Appeals from the judgment and orders dated October 12, 1961 and March 18, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petitions Nos. 122 of 1961 and 319 of 1960 respectively.

facts.text: The appeals were heard on March 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: March 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These three appeals which are on certificates of fitness granted by the High Courts

facts.text: Civil Appeal 598 of 1962 filed by Municipal Committee of Amravati against decision allowing 1st respondent's petition under Arts. 226 and 227.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal 598 of 1962 is an appeal from the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur and has been filed by the Municipal Committee of Amravati against a decision of the High Court allowing the 1st respondents petition under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Municipal Committee of Amravati established under C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Committee of Amravati has been established under the P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922  C.P. Berar Act II of 1922  hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: Terminal tax on goods imported by road or rail imposed by notification dated August 10, 1916, exempted silver, bullion and coin.

anchor.surface_text: a terminal tax on goods imported by road or rail had been imposed by the Munici- pality by virtue of a numberification dated August 10, 1916 on several specified kinds of goods. This numberification exempted silver, bullion and companyn from the operation of this tax.

facts.text: Notification of June 2, 1921 superseded 1916 notification, terminal tax confined to goods by rail.

anchor.surface_text: This was superseded by a numberification of June 2, 1921 under which the Schedules were modified and the terminal tax imposed was companyfined to goods imported into or exported out of the Municipal area by rail.

facts.text: No change effected in the taxes imposed after 1936.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification of June 1921 was amended from time to time by other items being added and the rates being increased but numberchange was effected in the taxes imposed after 1936.

facts.text: Terminal taxes continued after April 1, 1937 by s.143 of Government of India Act, 1935.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the distribution of taxing powers between the provinces and the Central Government under the Government of India Act, 1935 terminal taxes on goods carried by rail were assigned exclusively to the Federal Centre under item 58 of List I to Sch. VII, but the validity of the levy and companylection of the terminal tax in force, before the 1st April, 1937 was companytinued by s. 143 of the Government of India Act, 1935

facts.text: Taxes continued after January 26, 1950 by Article 277 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Their companytinuance after January 26, 1950 when after the repeal of the Government of India Act, 1935, the Consti- tution came into force with the same scheme of distribution of taxing power on the relevant item identical with that under the Government of India Act, was by reason of Art. 277

facts.text: Notification on December 1, 1959 added silver, silver jewellery, gold, gold jewellery, precious stones to terminal tax list, extended to road transport.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to January 26, 1950 there was a numberification on December 1, 1959, under which to the list of goods liable to terminal tax imported into or exported out of the Municipal area, number merely by rail, but also by road were added three new items-silver and silver jewellery, gold and gold jewellery, and precious stones,

facts.text: Procedure under s.67 followed and State Government sanctioned before 1959 notification.

anchor.surface_text: Before the numberification was issued the procedure indicated by s. 67 was gone through and the Government accorded their sanction to the rules made by the Municipal Committee for the imposition of the tax on the newly added articles.

facts.text: 1st respondent carried on business in gold, silver and precious stones within Amravati municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The validity of the tax imposed by this numberification was challenged by the 1st respondent who was carrying on business within Amravati municipality in gold, silver and precious stones,

facts.text: High Court by majority allowed the petition, granted certificate.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court by a majority accepted the companytention raised by the respondent and allowed the petition but granted a certificate of fitness and hence this appeal.

facts.text: In CA 695/62, notification issued December 9, 1960 imposing terminal tax on gunpowder by rail.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal a numberification was issued under sub-ss.  5  and  7  of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun- powder imported into or exported out of the municipal area by rail.

facts.text: No terminal tax on gunpowder imposed before the Constitution, admitted.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted that previous to the Constitution there was numbertax imposed on gun-powder.

facts.text: In CA 700/62, original notification imposing terminal taxes dated March 17, 1926 operative from April 1, 1926.

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeal 700 of 1962 the original numberification imposing terminal taxes in respect of goods companying into or going out of the municipal area by rail was one dated March 17, 1926 which was operative from April 1, 1926.

facts.text: Notification dated September 23, 1960 amended 1926 notification by adding new articles and increasing rates.

anchor.surface_text: This was amended by a numberification under s. 67  5  of the C.P. Berar Municipal Act, 1922 dated September 23, 1960 by which new articles were included to the list of items imported into or exported from the municipal area by rail subject to the terminal tax and besides the rate of tax on the previously existing items was also increased.

facts.text: Before 1st April 1937, articles by road not subject to terminal tax.

anchor.surface_text: whereas under the numberifications in force prior to 1st April 1937-when Part III of the Government of India Act was brought into force, articles imported into or exported out of the municipal area by road were number subject to the tax,

facts.text: Validity of post-Constitution impositions on new items not justified as fresh imposition, admitted.

anchor.surface_text: it is admitted that the validity of the imposition cannot be justified if it was a fresh imposition.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed all three appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court is, therefore companyrect and the appeal fails. [...] it follows that this appeal also fails and should be dismissed. [...] it would follow that this appeal should also fail.

issues.text: Whether the terminal taxes imposed by the appellant-municipal authorities under notifications issued under Ch. IX of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, subsequent to the coming into force of the Constitution are valid under Article 277 of the Constitution?

issues.text: Whether Article 277 saves the imposition of terminal tax on new items (such as silver, gold, precious stones, gunpowder) that were not being levied immediately before the commencement of the Constitution?

anchor.surface_text: the right to levy a terminal tax is now vested in the Union Parliament under Entry 89 of the Union List which reads Terminal taxes on goods or passengers carried by railway, sea or air taxes on railway fares and freights, so that if the levy by the appellant of the terminal tax on the newly added items, ... The question, therefore, is whether this was -the tax which was being levied by the municipal authority before the Constitution

issues.text: Whether Article 277 permits an increase in the rate of terminal tax or variation in its incidence post-Constitution?

issues.text: Whether mere vesting of power to levy terminal tax in the municipality pre-Constitution is sufficient for continuance under Article 277, or actual levy and collection is required?

anchor.surface_text: The argu- ment of the learned Attorney-General has to be rejected as lacking any substance, for on no construction, wide or narrow, of the expression levy in the phrase continue to be levied can such a case be comprehended. From the mere fact that a State enactment has authorised a municipality to levy a tax it cannot be said that a tax which had never been imposed was being lawfully levied

issues.text: Whether the meaning of 'levied' in Article 277 includes the imposition of tax on new articles of the same category as previously taxed articles?

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, there was no imposition of the charge now sought to be recovered prior to the Constitution, i.e., the Act did not impose the charge by s. 66 but merely enabled the Municipal Committee by appropriate procedure to impose the tax. If, of course, this power had been availed of and a charge had been imposed it would be a different matter.

anchor.surface_text: March 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These three appeals which are on certificates of fitness granted by the High Courts-the first by the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur and the two others by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh-raise a common question as regards the construction of Art. 277 of the Constitution and the validity of certain terminal taxes imposed by the respective appellant-municipal authorities under notifications issued under Ch. IX of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, subsequent to the coming into force of the Constitution, and so have been heard together.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Terminal taxes on rail/road post-1950 not continued under Art.277 unless exactly matching pre-Constitution levies; new items constitute fresh imposition beyond Union List entry 89

holdings.text: Article 277 does not save imposition of terminal tax on entirely new items like gunpowder not levied pre-Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun- powder imported into or exported out of the municipal area by rail. It is admitted that previous to the Constitution there was no tax imposed on gun-powder.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No pre-Constitution levy on gunpowder; identical to CA598/62 where new items rejected under Art.277 continuity requirement

holdings.text: Article 277 does not permit increase in rate of existing terminal taxes or addition of new articles post-Constitution

anchor.surface_text: This was amended by a notification under s. 67 (5) of the C.P. Berar Municipal Act, 1922 dated September 23, 1960 by which new articles were included to the list of items imported into or exported from the municipal area by rail subject to the terminal tax and besides the rate of tax on the previously existing items was also increased. [...] We can see no difference between the inclusion of new items and the increase in the rate of duty because if there is an increase it would not be a mere continuance of the duty which had been lawfully levied which is the only purpose and function of Art. 277.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Enhancement alters incidence; violates continuity under Art.277; no difference between new items and rate hikes

holdings.text: Mere statutory power to impose terminal tax pre-Constitution insufficient; actual levy and collection required under Article 277

anchor.surface_text: The argument of the learned Attorney-General has to be rejected as lacking any substance, for on no construction, wide or narrow, of the expression levy in the phrase continue to be levied can such a case be comprehended. From the mere fact that a State enactment has authorised a municipality to levy a tax it cannot be said that a tax which had never been imposed was being lawfully levied by the municipality, not to speak of the tax etc. collected being applied to the same purposes before the commencement of the Constitution as contemplated by the concluding portion of the Article.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual construction of 'levied' requires actual imposition/collection, not just authorization under s.66; linked to application to same purposes

holdings.text: 'Levy' under Article 277 requires actual pre-Constitution imposition on specific items, not mere enabling power or category expansion

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, there was no imposition of the charge now sought to be recovered prior to the Constitution, i.e., the Act did not impose the charge by s. 66 but merely enabled the Municipal Committee by appropriate procedure to impose the tax. If, of course, this power had been availed of and a charge had been imposed it would be a different matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No charge imposed pre-Constitution on new articles despite s.66 power; 'levied' means actual, not potential

holdings.text: Three-fold continuity test applies under Article 277: (1) lawfully levied pre by local authority for local area; (2) same identity/body/area/purposes; (3) no rate enhancement or incidence alteration

anchor.surface_text: 1 The tax must be one which was lawfully levied by a local authority for the purpose of a local area, 2 the identity of the body that collects the tax, the area for whose benefit the tax is to be utilised and the purposes for which the utilization is to take place continue to be the same, and 3 the rate of the tax is not enhanced nor its incidence in any manner altered, so that it continues to be the same tax.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts test from Rama Krishna case interpreting identical s.143(2) GIA 1935; submissions fail these tests

holdings.text: All three appeals fail as High Court decisions quashing post-Constitution terminal tax notifications are correct

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court is, therefore correct and the appeal fails. [...] it follows that this appeal also fails and should be dismissed. [...] it would follow that this appeal should also fail. [...] The judgment of the High Court allowing the writ petition of the respondent was therefore correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of Art.277 construction to facts of each appeal confirms invalidity of notifications

precedents.citation: Rama Krishna Ramanath v. The janpad Sabha, Gondia 1 [1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 70]

anchor.surface_text: Rama Krishna Ramanath v. The janpad Sabha, Gondia 1 . There it was submitted on behalf of the respondent-local authority that by virtue of s. 143 ( 2 ) of the Government of India Act the Provincial Legislature was vested with a plenary power to legislate in respect of every tax which was being lawfully levied by local authorities prior to the commencement of the Government of India Act. This Court rejected that contention and observed Section 143 ( 2 ) which is a saving clause and obviously designed to prevent a dislocation of the finances of Local Governments and of local authorities by reason of the coming into force of the provisions of the Government of India Act distributing heads of taxation on lines different from those which prevailed before that date, cannot be construed as one conferring a plenary power to legislate on those topics till such time as the Central Legislature intervened. Such a construction would necessarily involve a power in the Provincial Legislature to enhance the rates of taxation-a result we must say from which Mr. Sanyal did not shrink, but having regard to the language of the section 1 1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 70.

precedents.case_name: Rama Krishna Ramanath v. Janpad Sabha, Gondia
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 143(2) of the Government of India Act, 1935, identical to Art. 277, is a saving clause to prevent financial dislocation and does not confer plenary legislative power to impose new taxes of the same type, enhance rates, or expand the range; it allows only continuance of the identical tax being levied, with same body, area, purposes, rate, and incidence.
precedents.cited_holding: Section 143(2) ... cannot be construed as one conferring a plenary power to legislate on those topics till such time as the Central Legislature intervened. Such a construction would necessarily involve a power in the Provincial Legislature to enhance the rates of taxation ... this construction must be rejected.

precedents.citation: Chuttilal v. Bagmal and Balwantrai 1 I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339

anchor.surface_text: In this connection learned Counsel for the respondent referred us to the decision in Chuttilal v. Bagmal and Balwantrai 1 where the relationship between the levy and the application of the tax has been referred to as an aid to the construction of the expression continue to be levied in Art. 277. We find ourselves in agreement with the views there expressed. The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339.

precedents.cited_proposition: The relationship between levy and application of the proceeds of the tax aids the construction of 'continue to be levied' in Art. 277, indicating that levy includes collection since only collected tax has proceeds to apply to purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. outcome.relief_summary: All three appeals (Civil Appeals Nos. 598, 695 and 700 of 1962) dismissed. High Court judgments upheld quashing notifications imposing terminal taxes on new items (silver, gold, precious stones, gunpowder etc.) and increasing rates, as not protected under Article 277 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: March 3, 1964. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by AYYANGAR, J.-These three appeals which are on certificates of fitness granted by the High Courts-the first by the High Court of Bombay at Nagpur and the two others by the High Court of Madhya Pradesh-raise a common question as regards the construction of Art. 277 of the Constitution and the validity of certain terminal taxes imposed by the respective appellant-municipal authorities under notifications issued under Ch. IX of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, subsequent to the coming into force of the Constitution, and so have been heard together.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-

In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun- powder imported into or exported out of the municipal area by rail. It is admitted that previous to the Constitution there was no tax imposed on gun-powder.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-

This was amended by a notification under s. 67 (5) of the C.P. Berar Municipal Act, 1922 dated September 23, 1960 by which new articles were included to the list of items imported into or exported from the municipal area by rail subject to the terminal tax and besides the rate of tax on the previously existing items was also increased. [...] We can see no difference between the inclusion of new items and the increase in the rate of duty because if there is an increase it would not be a mere continuance of the duty which had been lawfully levied which is the only purpose and function of Art. 277.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-

The argument of the learned Attorney-General has to be rejected as lacking any substance, for on no construction, wide or narrow, of the expression levy in the phrase continue to be levied can such a case be comprehended. From the mere fact that a State enactment has authorised a municipality to levy a tax it cannot be said that a tax which had never been imposed was being lawfully levied by the municipality, not to speak of the tax etc. collected being applied to the same purposes before the commencement of the Constitution as contemplated by the concluding portion of the Article.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-

edges.explanation: Holding that 'levy' requires actual imposition, not mere enabling power, undercuts the sufficiency of the empowering provision in c6 (Section 66) for post-Constitution continuity

anchor.surface_text: tion of the Article. Coming next to what one might term the narrower submission of Mr. Setalvad we do number find it possible to agree with it either.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly, there was no imposition of the charge now sought to be recovered prior to the Constitution, i.e., the Act did not impose the charge by s. 66 but merely enabled the Municipal Committee by appropriate procedure to impose the tax. If, of course, this power had been availed of and a charge had been imposed it would be a different matter.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-

edges.explanation: Three-fold continuity test under Article 277 requires actual pre-levy, undercutting reliance on mere empowering provision c6 without prior actual imposition

anchor.surface_text: by increasing the rates of duty. This companysideration apart, it is number possible to read the words numberwithstanding that the taxes etc. are men

edges.explanation: Three-fold continuity test under Article 277 supports the holding that taxes are not saved
Three-fold test's first limb (lawfully levied pre) supports h5's narrow interpretation of 'levy' as actual imposition
Three-fold continuity test under Article 277 is the doctrinal basis for assessing the issue of tax validity post-Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: 1 The tax must be one which was lawfully levied by a local authority for the purpose of a local area, 2 the identity of the body that collects the tax, the area for whose benefit the tax is to be utilised and the purposes for which the utilization is to take place continue to be the same, and 3 the rate of the tax is not enhanced nor its incidence in any manner altered, so that it continues to be the same tax.

The decision of the High Court is, therefore, correct and the appeal fails. I.L.R. 1956 Madhya Bharat 339. CIVIL APPEAL No. 695 OF 1962. In this appeal a notification was issued under sub-ss. (5) and (7) of s. 67 of the C.P. Berar Municipalities Act, 1922, on December 9, 1960 imposing a terminal tax on gun-
